In a patient, corneal scraping reveals narrow angled septate hyphae. Which of the following is likely etiologic agent?
questions.explanation:
Option 1
  • Mucor: Broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide angle branching
  • Histoplasma capsulatum: invivo – yeast like form
  • Candida: GPOBYC: Gram positive oval budding yeast cell.
Option 3
  1. Narrow Septate hyaline hyphae with acute angle branching suggest the diagnosis of Aspergillus infection.
  2. Clinical manifestations of Aspergillus:
    • Pulmonary aspergillosis (MC form): Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), Asthma, Extrinsic allergic alveolitis, Aspergilloma (fungal ball) and Chronic cavitary pulmonary aspergillosis.
    • Invasive sinusitis, chronic granulomatous sinusitis, maxillary fungal ball and allergic fungal sinusitis.
    • Keratitis, endophthalmitis & Otitis externa.
    • Others: Endocarditis, brain abscess, skin lesions and onychomycosis.

A chest physician performs bronchoscopy in the procedure room of the outpatient department to make the instrument safe for use in the next patient waiting outside, the most appropriate method to disinfect the endoscope is by –
questions.explanation:
Option 1, 2, 3, 4

Glutaraldehyde

  • Mode of action: combine with nucleic acids and proteins and inactivate them, probably by crosslinking and alkylating the molecules.
  • Glutaraldehyde is less toxic, less irritant and less corrosive, hence is best used to sterilize endoscopes and cystoscopes.
  • Glutaraldehyde is especially effective against tubercle bacilli, fungi, and viruses. It can be used for cleaning cystoscopes and bronchoscopes, corrugated rubber anesthetic tubes and face masks, plastic endotracheal tubes, metal instruments, and polythene tubing.
  • It is used as 2% concentration (2% cidex) for 20 min.but may require as long as 12 hours to destroy all spores.
  • It has to be activated by alkalinization before use. Once activated, it remains active only for 14 days.

questions.explanation:
Rocky Mountain spotted fever Treponema pallidum Coxsackievirus Disseminated Histoplasmosis
  • RASH evolves as erythematous blanchable macules, papules, and petechiae
  • Appear 3 or 4 days later
  • Initially, over wrists and ankles
  • Spreads centrally to the limbs, trunk, and face
  • PALM-SOLES usually involved
  • Other findings: palatal petechiae, periorbital edema, acute abdomen

 

 
  • Eruptions are macular rashes and symmetrically distributed, almost always involving the face and forehead (individual lesions tend to be indurated; the colour may vary considerably, most often presenting as a subdued red rather than a bright red lesion)
  • Papules on the genitalia or within the oral cavity
  • Papular lesions on the palms of the hands or the soles of the feet
  • Generalized pustular or follicular lesions
  • Generalized lymphadenopathy

 

 

 

 

 
  • Mouth or throat pain secondary to the enanthem.
  • Vesicles surrounded by a thin halo of erythema eventually rupture and form superficial ulcers with a grey-yellow base surrounded by an erythematous rim.
  • The exanthem can be macular, vesicular, or papular. The lesions are non-pruritic and typically not painful.
  • The exanthem occurs on the dorsum of hands, feet, buttocks, legs, and arms.

 
  • Characteristic lesions include nodules, papules, plaques, ulcers, vesicles, pustules, abscesses, and generalized dermatitis.
  • Less commonly, exfoliative erythroderma, necrotizing vasculitis, cellulitis, panniculitis, petechiae, purpura, and ecchymosis can be seen

Consider the following statements and choose the correct answer? Statement 1:-Fluid restriction and not medication is the best for management of asymptomatic hyponatremia with serum Sodium less than 120 mEq/L, in patients of cirrhosis with oedema. options.label: D
options.text: Statement 1 is correct and Statement 2 is wrong

questions.explanation:
Fluid restriction and not medication is the best for management of asymptomatic hyponatremia with serum sodium less than 120 mEq/L and in patients of cirrhosis with edema.

Asymptomatic hyponatremia will respond to fluid restriction.

Symptomatic hyponatremia with neurological implications must be corrected at a rate of 4-8mEq/L over 24hours with 3% Hypertonic saline
Conivaptan decreases B.P. and increases risk of variceal bleeding and so relatively contraindicated in cirrhotics with hyponatremia

Conivaptan acts on V IA and V2 receptors. V IA stimulation is associated with vasoconstrictive, mitogenic, and possibly platelet aggregative effects. Conivaptan causes inhibition of VIA receptors and is beneficial for patients with CHF with concomitanthypertension and atherosclerotic disease.

In contrast, the very same effects derived from V IA inhibition can be harmful for hypotensive patients or cirrhotic patients with dilated splanchnic beds and variceal bleeds.

Further dilatation of the splanchnic bed and interference with platelet aggregation by V IA inhibition could exacerbate variceal bleeding.

questions.text: Match List I with List II and select the correct answer using the code given below the lists: List I (Emergency drugs) List II (Clinical condition) A. Amiodarone 1. 1st-degree heart Block B. Adenosine 2. Atrial fibrillation C. Digoxin 3. Ventricular tachycardia D. Atropine 4. Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia Code: A B C D
questions.explanation:
Amiodarone Ventricular tachycardia Prolongs the APD of the current generated due to re-entry or automaticity. This results in the decrease in firing frequency of the ectopic focus and helps in termination of arrhythmia.
Adenosine P.S.V.T Prolongs AV nodal delay and re-establishes the superiority of SA node.
Digoxin Atrial fibrillation Digoxin acts on AV node and slows the conduction of impulses generated from ectopic focus down to bundle of HIS. Hence it is used for rate control and also useful for management of concomitant CHF
Atropine Ist degree heart block Atropine increases firing of the sinoatrial node (atria) and conduction through the atrioventricular node (AV) of the heart by blocking the action of the vagus nerve. It is not useful for Mobitz II and third-degree heart block.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding scleral rupture?

options.label: A
options.text: Seidel's test can be used to know site of rupture as it can elicit aqueous leakage

options.label: C
options.text: Traumatic rupture usually occurs at weak points, like at insertion of recti muscles

options.label: D
options.text: It can cause angle recession glaucoma

questions.correct_answer: D. It can cause angle recession glaucoma

questions.text: A 35-year-old cricket player presented to OPD with complaints of headache and palpitations. O/E - He has a standing BP 190/100 mm Hg and sitting BP-180/100 mm Hg. He also has an irregularly irregular rhythm, double apical impulse, and bilateral basal crepitations. But no murmurs could be auscultated and heart rate could not be determined. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Condition Features
Left atrial Myxoma More common in a young female with symptoms of myxoma platypnea and low cardiac output since the tumor limits the blood flow into the left ventricle.
Mitral regurgitation Ruled out as no murmur was auscultated in the patient
Cor pulmonale Ruled out as primary lung disease or findings of RVF are absent
LVH

Points in favor of diagnosis:

  1. Hypertension can lead to LVH causing double apical impulse.
  2. HTN can lead to diastolic dysfunction and impacts the atria leading to atrial fibrillation and irregular pulse
  3. Basal crepitations can be explained by atrial fibrillation.
  4. BP changes in standing and supine position are normal (less than equal to 10mm Hg)
